abstract: The drawings, stark and elegant, reflect the artist's calm demeanor: a blue vase holding a cluster of slim branches. Two dancers with legs extended in graceful plies. A bowl of fruit penciled delicately against a white background.   Raymond E. started sketching when he was 9, papering his bedroom walls with pictures of cartoon characters. But by the time he was a teen-ager, severe emotional problems ended his hobby and cast a pall over the larger landscape of his life. He spent 14 years in psychiatric hospitals, being treated for successive nervous breakdowns.
lead_paragraph: The drawings, stark and elegant, reflect the artist's calm demeanor: a blue vase holding a cluster of slim branches. Two dancers with legs extended in graceful plies. A bowl of fruit penciled delicately against a white background.

abstract: The men and women who deliver food each day to 35 homebound elderly people in Jackson Heights, Queens, fill a need for friendship as well as nourishment. The  recipients are widowed or ailing, or both, and are no longer able to cook. In this program, the food is carried on foot by volunteers, so they call it Meals-on-Heels. Boris Iskhakov, above, took lunch the other day to Rose Castellblanco, right and below. The service is run through the Catherine Sheridan Senior Center, which is supported by the Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Brooklyn and Queens, an agency supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.   SARAH JAY      Previously recorded $2,553,838.92 Recorded yesterday $148,944.00
lead_paragraph: The men and women who deliver food each day to 35 homebound elderly people in Jackson Heights, Queens, fill a need for friendship as well as nourishment. The recipients are widowed or ailing, or both, and are no longer able to cook. In this program, the food is carried on foot by volunteers, so they call it Meals-on-Heels. Boris Iskhakov, above, took lunch the other day to Rose Castellblanco, right and below. The service is run through the Catherine Sheridan Senior Center, which is supported by the Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Brooklyn and Queens, an agency supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. SARAH JAY

abstract: Selina H. lost her older sister to AIDS in 1994, leaving behind three children. One child went to live with an aunt, one stayed with a maternal grandmother in Manhattan and one moved to South Carolina to be with a paternal grandmother.         Last summer, when the disease was diagnosed in another sister, it was Ms. H.'s turn to take in one of the surviving children. She got custody of her nephew Calixto, who was 6 and had just tested positive for H.I.V.

abstract: In retrospect, there were some early clues that Diana Cortez was getting sick. It was odd, for instance, that Diana, a 17-year-old, could not keep pace with her social worker, who often invited her on walks. She seemed increasingly  clumsy, too, occasionally dropping a cup or a glass.         Sometimes, her legs gave out as she rose from a chair. That happened earlier  this year in front of Martha Pacheco, her social worker.

abstract: In the shadowy hallway of a South Bronx apartment building, Maggie V. has posted a message to remind herself of past struggles. Its bold letters read, "Housing is a Human Right." At 30, Ms. V. is a single mother studying to become a social worker. Her goal is to help other women from Puerto Rico, her homeland, find affordable housing and avoid the battles she had to fight not long ago.   She came to New York from Puerto Rico in 1987, and for the first two years she stayed with relatives in a crowded apartment. But in 1988, Ms. V. became pregnant, and her family told her to find new housing. She searched for months, but nothing was affordable. She ended up renting a room in a cheap motel in Queens, where the manager sexually harassed and robbed her.
lead_paragraph: In the shadowy hallway of a South Bronx apartment building, Maggie V. has posted a message to remind herself of past struggles. Its bold letters read, "Housing is a Human Right." At 30, Ms. V. is a single mother studying to become a social worker. Her goal is to help other women from Puerto Rico, her homeland, find affordable housing and avoid the battles she had to fight not long ago.

abstract: Tajiauna Spence and her children became homeless last year when a fire broke out in an apartment below hers. Now they live in a homeless shelter in Brownsville, Brooklyn.
snippet: Tajiauna Spence and her children became homeless last year when a fire broke out in an apartment below hers. Now they live in a homeless shelter in Brownsville, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Tajiauna Spence and three of her daughters ate dinner at a McDonald’s in Chelsea late last month. Her grandson, Styles, was the center of the group’s affections as he played with his gloves and made random demands.

abstract: Beatrice J. adopted Angel, a 4-month-old baby girl, and soon made a discovery.    ''I gave her a brightly colored toy,  and she couldn't follow it,'' she said. ''So I gave her a toy that made noise and she followed it, and that's how I knew she was blind.''
lead_paragraph: Beatrice J. adopted Angel, a 4-month-old baby girl, and soon made a discovery.

abstract: In the Philippines, Rey Canunayon committed himself to nonprofit work. A new life in Queens has been challenging, but the Neediest Cases has been an ally.
snippet: In the Philippines, Rey Canunayon committed himself to nonprofit work. A new life in Queens has been challenging, but the Neediest Cases has been an ally.
lead_paragraph: In 2007, Rey Canunayon and his wife, MaryGwen, immigrated to the United States from the island of Mindanao in the Philippines. In doing so, they were fulfilling their family’s dreams.

keywords.value: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund

abstract: Ernestine Grant’s mother died when she was 11, and her father before she graduated from high school. That did not deter her dream of going to college.
snippet: Ernestine Grant’s mother died when she was 11, and her father before she graduated from high school. That did not deter her dream of going to college.
lead_paragraph: Ernestine Grant’s mother, Ethel, adored Christmas. And so it was not surprising that one morning a week before the holiday she was heading out of her Brooklyn apartment in search of additional gifts. Ethel Grant got as far as the door before she cried out for her husband and crumpled to the floor. She had been stricken by a massive stroke. She lasted a week in the hospital. She died on her beloved Christmas Eve.

abstract: A couple’s dog therapy program on Staten Island brings a bright spot into days often marred by pain, age and illness.
snippet: A couple’s dog therapy program on Staten Island brings a bright spot into days often marred by pain, age and illness.
lead_paragraph: With a jingle of tags and bells, Harley, Dolly, Feather and Bailey trot past a bank of poinsettias and into the Clove Lakes Health Care and Rehabilitation Center, a nursing home on Staten Island. The lobby erupts, as if rock stars just walked in.

abstract: Out of regular work since 2008, Aldine Francois of Brooklyn lost her mother and eight other relatives in a house collapse caused by the earthquake in Haiti.
snippet: Out of regular work since 2008, Aldine Francois of Brooklyn lost her mother and eight other relatives in a house collapse caused by the earthquake in Haiti.
lead_paragraph: Sitting in her living room in Ocean Hill, Brooklyn, Aldine Francois, 27, peeled layers of silk cloth away from a white book with golden pages. It was a photo album holding the most recent pictures she had of her mother, from a wedding in July 2009.

abstract: Devorah Weiss, a social worker for several groups, spends much of her busy time helping the newly needy from the middle class.
snippet: Devorah Weiss, a social worker for several groups, spends much of her busy time helping the newly needy from the middle class.
lead_paragraph: For emergencies, there is 911. For noise complaints, there is 311. For those in dire straits on Staten Island, there is Devorah Weiss, a social worker whose cellphone number is passed on as a last resort.
